docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 India and Pakistan Pledge New Effort on Kashmir India and Pakistan pledged to make a new effort to reconcile their differences over the disputed territory of Kashmir. After three days of talks, their foreign ministers agreed to make Kashmir a separate topic for discussion within broader negotiations aimed at achieving detente. The dispute has been the biggest irritant between the two countries for much of the last 50 years. A6 France Debates Arrests The French Justice Minister, Elisabeth Guigou, wondered aloud if gendarmes had gone too far in a huge sweep against pedophiles after four of those arrested apparently committed suicide. Some 800 people were picked up, but only 24 remained under arrest. Human rights groups charged that defendants' rights were trampled, and relatives of one man believed to have killed himself said they would sue. A6 U.S. Decried as Polluter European leaders came before the United Nations and singled out the United States for failing to take forceful action on environmental issues, like reducing emissions of greenhouse gases that contribute to global warming. They had gathered to review how the world has fallen short of the ambitious goals set at a conference five years ago in Rio de Janeiro. A9 Intrigue Surrounds Pol Pot The enemies of Pol Pot, the Khmer Rouge leader, are likely to kill him rather than let him testify at a trial where he could implicate them, Cambodia's First Prime Minister Norodom Ranariddh said. He did not identify any country or person in particular, but China was once a Khmer Rouge patron and various Thai interests continue to have close links to the guerrillas. A10 Canadian officials, meanwhile, expressed doubt that their genocide law could be used to seek extradition of Pol Pot, as the United States has suggested. The suspect would have to be present in Canada, officials noted, and Canada has no extradition treaty with Cambodia. A10 Effort to Revive Tories William Hague, the new Tory leader, pledged to turn Britain's battered Conservatives into a ''party of the future,'' but decided to reinstall a party chairman from the Thatcher era. The choice was considered surprising because Mr. Hague has made a commitment to eliminating scandal, and the new chairman, Cecil Parkinson, 65, was once forced to leave government after his parliamentary secretary revealed she was pregnant with his child. A11 U.N. Opens Effort on Cyprus In a letter to the Security Council, United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan has called for a ''sustained process of direct negotiations'' to reach a comprehensive settlement in Cyprus. He notified the council that the leaders of the Greek and Turkish Cypriot communities would hold face-to-face talks in July. (Reuters) NATIONAL A12-17, B10-11 In Reversal, Court Allows Aid in Religious Schools The Supreme Court overturned one of its own precedents to declare that the Constitution permits public school systems to send teachers into parochial schools to teach remedial and supplemental classes to needy children. The 5-to-4 decision ends a 12-year period during which public school systems, obliged by Federal law to provide the special services to all students who qualified but barred by the Court from delivering them on parochial school premises, had to use expensive alternatives. A1 President Clinton suffered a setback in the Whitewater investigation when the Court refused to review a subpoena that orders White House lawyers to surrender notes they had taken of conversations with Hillary Rodham Clinton. A1 The Court also ruled that states may confine violent sex offenders in mental hospitals after they have served their criminal sentences, even if the offenders are not so mentally ill as to meet a state's ordinary criteria for civil commitment against their will. B11 Army Hearing Is Opened Civilian judges on the military's highest court ordered the Army to open to the public a hearing involving sexual misconduct charges against the Army's most senior enlisted soldier. Lawyers said they could not recall any instance in which the court, which has jurisdiction over the entire military justice system, had ordered one of the military services to open a hearing that the service wanted closed. A17 Senate Alters Health Plan Leaders of the Senate Finance Committee said they had agreed to revise their proposal to make affluent elderly people pay more for Medicare. The change would retain the idea of such a ''means test,'' but would make it easier for the Government to administer. A13 Tobacco Pact Under Attack Critics began a concerted attack on the proposed $368 billion tobacco liability settlement, citing numerous provisions they consider too favorable to cigarette makers and demanding that major portions of the agreement be rewritten. Dr. C. Everett Koop, the former Surgeon General and longtime anti-tobacco crusader, called the deal ''deeply flawed.'' A17 A lawyer for the Liggett Group, the first tobacco company to negotiate a deal with government officials, said that the settlement reached with other leading tobacco companies last week could force it into bankruptcy. A16 Hubbell Faulted in Audit Former Associate Attorney General Webster L. Hubbell overstated the amount of work he performed as a lobbyist for the Los Angeles Department of Airports in 1994 and the city should seek to recover $24,750 in fees, an inquiry by the city controller's office concluded. B11 NEW YORK/REGION B1-9 Railway Workers Lose Asbestos Exposure Case The Supreme Court ruled that 140 pipe fitters and underground workers from Grand Central Terminal exposed to cancer-causing asbestos dust are not entitled to seek damages from Metro North Commuter Railroad for emotional distress before the onset of actual disease. The ruling noted that the lead plaintiff, Michael Buckley, had ''suffered wrong at the hands of a negligent employer,'' but with no signs of disease or emotional distress he could not seek recourse. B1 Mayor Gains Union Support The largest firefighters union plans to endorse the re-election effort of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who so far is faring better in the battle for union support than Republicans typically do in New York City. B1 SPORTS B13-19 SCIENCE TIMES C1-8 Diabetes Threshold Moved Levels of blood sugar that have long been accepted as normal are actually too high and should be considered a sign of diabetes, according to new guidelines issued by the American Diabetes Association and endorsed by Federal health authorities. A1 Obesity Linked to Genetics Human obesity, a condition affecting a third of Americans, has for the first time been found to have a genetic cause, at least in some cases. The condition, a defect in a gene that controls body weight, has been found in two cousins studied by scientists in England. C3 ARTS C9-19 Insects Invade Hollywood At least a half-dozen scripts involving insects are in various stages of development and production in Hollywood, turning them into a formidable screen presence. The last wave of insect films took place at the outset of the atomic age, exemplified by ''Them!,'' the 1954 classic about giant ants running wild in the Southwest after an atomic test. C9 BUSINESS DAY D1-19 Gates Creates Foundation William H. Gates, the software entrepreneur sometimes criticized for being too slow to give away his billions, is creating a new foundation that intends to spend $200 million over five years to bring new computers and the Internet into the nation's public libraries. D1 Dow Plummets at Close The stock market plunged in a late wave of selling that turned what seemed to be a routine session into the worst of the year. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 192.25 points, or 2.47 percent, to 7,604.26. D1 Compaq to Buy Tandem The Compaq Computer Corporation agreed to acquire Tandem Computers in a stock swap valued around $3 billion. D1 Pennzoil Is Target of Bid Union Pacific Resources began a hostile $4 billion offer for the Pennzoil Company, seeking to capture rich petroleum reserves and a venerable brand name. D4 Business Digest D1 OBITUARIES D20 Betty Shabazz The widow of slain civil rights leader Malcolm X who sought to preserve his memory and teachings while raising their six daughters and making a career as a college official was 61. A1 EDITORIAL A18-19 Editorials: A trial for Pol Pot; public teachers in parochial schools; Steven R. Weisman on the Denver summit. Columns: A. M. Rosenthal, Russell Baker. headline.main: FRESH GUIDELINES REDEFINE DIABETES IN BROADER TERMS

docs.abstract: New guidelines issued by American Diabetes Assn and endorsed by Federal health authorities say levels of blood sugar long accepted as normal are actually too high and should be considered sign of diabetes; call for testing of all healthy people age 45 and older every three years, with testing starting earlier and done more often in people with higher risk, including those who are obese, black, Hispanic, American Indian or closely related to someone with diabetes; researchers hope earlier detection will improve treatment and prevent other medical complications; possible medical impact of new guidelines discussed; charts (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Levels of blood sugar that have long been accepted as normal are actually too high and should be considered a sign of diabetes, according to new guidelines issued yesterday by the American Diabetes Association and endorsed by Federal health authorities. The guidelines call for testing all healthy people age 45 and older -- about 77 million Americans -- every three years, and are expected to lead to the detection of 2 million new cases.

headline.main: Despite Warnings, the Sales of Diet Drugs Soar

docs.abstract: Market continues to boom in weight-loss drugs, despite warnings about side effects, doubts about efficacy, and doctors' widespread prescribing to patients who do not qualify as obese; photo (Special section, Women's Health) (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: WEIGHT-LOSS experts have yet to create a silver bullet for fighting fat, but consumers are searching harder than ever for one. From 1995 to 1996, sales of anti-obesity drugs nearly tripled to $526 million from $179 million. Obesity ranks second to smoking as a cause of preventable death in the United States, contributing to 300,000 deaths a year. But while there are no reliable numbers, medical practitioners think that much of the increase in drug sales was going not to the seriously obese but to the merely heavy, said Dr. Louis Aronne, who runs a weight-loss clinic affiliated with New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

docs.lead_paragraph: A woman's life cycle can sometimes seem like an obstacle course in which she must dodge an increasing number of health threats. In reality, as medical experts point out, every stage in a woman's life has its health benefits. Indeed, women typically pass through long periods of essentially good health. Risks can be reduced if good habits are nurtured early on. And eve late in the game, women can undertake preventive measures that improve the quality of life.

headline.main: Is There a Doctor in the House? Whatever Kind You Need

docs.abstract: Women's health centers are springing up around New York City and nationwide, inspired by the demographics of baby boomers, surging interest in women's health, and fierce competition among hospitals for customers in a restructured health-care economy; scene at Columbia-Presbyterian women's center, which offers its 4,000 customers the equivalent of a 'medical mall,' described; photos (Special section, Women's Health) (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: SURE, there are magazines in the waiting room of the Columbia-Presbyterian Center for Women's Health: Metropolitan Home, Vanity Fair and the like. But the patients would rather yak -- strangers turned friends as they exchange remedies for hot flashes, brittle bones, depression or obesity in what is fast becoming the medical version of the kaffeeklatsch, Tupperware party or consciousness-raising group of old. It is a typical day at the three-year-old center in an Upper East Side high-rise, a stone's throw from Bloomingdale's. A woman in her late 40's is here to see the obesity specialist and nutritionist to find out whether she is a candidate for the hot new appetite suppressants, although she has a heart condition. A woman in her 50's is here to see the cardiologist, osteoporosis expert and endocrinologist as she considers the pros and cons of hormone-replacement therapy. And a woman near 70, who has broken more bones than Humpty Dumpty, is here for the results of her latest bone-density test and to celebrate the startling regeneration she has experienced with a new drug.
